title: The Living SEB app
text:
Overview
The Living SEB App is an interactive Shiny application designed to explore, synthesize, and meta-analyse all available cross-sectional studies included in the Living SEB Project. It provides a transparent, continuously updated interface to examine study characteristics, extract effect sizes, and run reproducible analyses in real time.
Built as part of a broader effort to create a living, open, and cumulative evidence base on Social, Emotional, and Behavioral skills (SEB), the app allows researchers, students, and practitioners to interact with the data without needing to write any R code.

title: The Living SEB app
section: What you can do with the app
text:
What you can do with the app

Browse all included SEB studies with filters for samples, designs, measures, and variables.
Inspect effect sizes and metadata for every association extracted in the review.
Run on-the-fly meta-analyses (random/fixed models, moderators, subgroup analyses).
Download the dataset used in the app for further analysis in R or other tools.
Track updates as new studies are added to the living review.

Structural Equation Modeling 



Course website: https://enricotoffalini.github.io/SEM-course/
Short description
This course introduces the foundations of Structural Equation Modeling (SEM), covering latent variables, CFA, path analysis, and measurement invariance. You will learn how to specify, estimate, and test SEM models in R using the lavaan package, as well as perform power analysis through simulation.

Who this is useful for

PhD students and early-career researchers who need a compact, applied introduction to SEM

Teachers who want ready-made R exercises and examples and slides to integrate in their own courses

title: A shiny app for clusters that are not there
text:
Clusters That Are Not There is a Shiny application designed to help researchers quantify inferential risks when applying clustering methods such as Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM) or k-means. Inspired by the article Clusters That Are Not There (Toffalini et al., 2024), the app provides an accessible interface to run Monte Carlo simulations that evaluate Type I error, power, and classification accuracy under conditions commonly found in psychological research.
The core message of the paper is simple but crucial:
Clustering methods can easily ‚Äúdetect‚Äù clusters even when none exist ‚Äî especially when assumptions such as normality or local independence are violated.
This app offers an intuitive way to test these risks before running cluster analyses on real data.
‚û°Ô∏è Explore the app: https://psicostat.shinyapps.io/clustersimulation-demo/
‚û°Ô∏è Manuscript: Toffalini et al., https://doi.org/10.1002/ijop.13246 (Open Access)

title: A shiny app for clusters that are not there
text:
What the App Does
The app implements the simulation logic described in the manuscript, allowing users to:

Simulate datasets with custom characteristics:

sample size
number of indicators
correlations
skewness and kurtosis
effect size (d) between true clusters

Estimate Type I error
How often does a method detect multiple clusters when the data truly come from one population? (e.g., GMM may show inflated Type I error under modest skewness)
Estimate Power
How often does the method correctly detect two clusters when they truly exist? (e.g., with d = .50 and N = 700, power is extremely low for both GMM and k-means)
Assess classification accuracy
Using the Adjusted Rand Index, the app reveals how often detected clusters actually match the true underlying structure (k-means may detect ‚Äútwo clusters‚Äù with 100% power but classify individuals no better than chance (Adjusted Rand Index ‚âà .06)).

title: A shiny app for clusters that are not there
text:
Why This Matters
Clustering is popular in psychology, but the assumptions behind common methods are often unmet. The manuscript shows several scenarios where:

Moderate skewness (skew = .50) yields 48% false positives for GMM in our simulation (p.7)
Modest correlations (r = .35) produce 100% false positives for k-means (p.8‚Äì9)
Large sample sizes exacerbate the problem for GMM (p.12)
GMM may ‚Äúcreate‚Äù clusters to compensate for skewed distributions (Figure 6, p.13)

These are exactly the pitfalls the app helps users explore and understand.

title: Living SEB project
text:
The Living SEB Project (https://github.com/feracotommaso/living_SEB_review) is an open, continuously updated research initiative that compiles and synthesizes all available cross-sectional studies on Strength‚ÄìEmotion‚ÄìBehavior (SEB) associations.
Its goal is to create a transparent, reproducible, and dynamic evidence base that evolves as new research emerges.
The project provides access to a living database, a suite of analytic tools, a public preregistration, and a detailed methodological paper explaining the full workflow. It is designed to support researchers, students, and meta-analysts who need reliable, continually updated evidence from the SEB literature.

title: Living SEB project
text:
Why a ‚ÄúLiving‚Äù approach?
Traditional meta-analyses quickly become outdated as new studies accumulate.
The Living SEB Project uses a living evidence workflow ‚Äî an approach that ensures:

rapid integration of new findings
fully reproducible synthesis pipelines
transparent tracking of updates
continuous availability of up-to-date results

This allows the SEB literature to remain current, cumulative, and open for researchers and practitioners.
